The 140% rule is typical for civil aircraft and I think the Falcon 9 was designed to that rule anyway, it was only older expendable boosters that were built to 125%. Bare in mind that failure load is calculated against a materials allowable stress, this factor also has a safety margin included in it, firstly it is normally the point at which it will start to yield (bend) not catastrophically fail and secondly it is a minimum strength based on sampling, the average strength of the material will be higher.

Doing some basic maths a second stage with a 10m diameter heat shield lands at about 50mph a 20m diameter heat shield lands at 25mph, if you could accurately land on a stunt airbag it would be perfectly feasible to land the second stage without a parachute. One other potential way that would need less integration would be to trail a ballute behind the craft to allow it to enter nose first and then place a heat shield on the nose, the second stage is lighter than a dragon capsule.

comment_text: hoax

19:04 Economics 101. Why? Marketshare.

If you want to conquer the market the fastest, you need to undercut your competition with a large amount. The larger the difference, the more you attract customers, the more marketshare you get. For a 3% cut, many customers will not bother, either because they know the space-companies from dealings with before, have more faith in the reliability, national interests, launch windows, etc. for a 30% cut, they all will be interested.

If Elon plays his cards right, within 10 years, he will have put the other classic space-companies out of business. Ariane, for instance, will get some uppercuts - they already more expensive as it is, and they only envisage partially re-usability after Ariane 6... By that time, the BFR will already be there, undercutting everything they have. If SpaceX aggressively hugely undercut all others from the start, they will all go bankrupt, and he gets a large marketshare, with the only future competition coming from (also) new companies, like Blue Origin.

So: it does make sense.

I got this from Elon Musk's teleconference: It is the largest titanium forging

We are now going consistently with the titanium grid fins and have now moved away completely from the aluminum grid fins that were non-reusable because they got cooked pretty hard during re-entry, particularly during geostationary re-entry. So we have, we think it's the largest titanium forging in the world. Looks like a giant bear claw, the new grid fins. It looks really cool, I think. And they're capable of withstanding on the order of 1000 degrees Celsius, 2000 degrees Fahrenheit, thereabouts. And requires no work between flights, which is also great.

SpaceX would pass on the savings if they want to grow the market. Because it takes time to plan, design and build a satellite, there is little point in cutting the prices too quickly. Your commenters need to look at a close up of the glorious titanium grid fins. They appear to be cast to near net shape, then forged to created the serrated edges. This way the sharp leading edge is strengthened by manipulating the grain structure; forged! During supersonic reentry the sharp scalloped geometry creates attached shockwave interference (xxxxs similar to what you see in single engine testing)! There is a relatively easy solution for landing on the vacuum engine. The only big difference is the size of the nozzle so one could devise a way to jettison the end of the nozzle just before re-entry. There are of course some other things which will need adjustment but I think most can be done in the control software.

It might even make sense to reduce the nozzle length even further to make it underexpanded which would reduce the thrust enough for the now very light vehicle while keeping its combustion stable. The downside is of course that you throw away the nozzle which is quite an expensive item but of course you save the rest of the engine and stage which costs many times more than the expensive nozzle. The nozzle is quite fragile and probably would be damaged anyway even by aerodynamic forces so might as well discard it.

300 flights with 30-50 boosters is 6-10 flights per booster. Still, I'd have thought the refurb cost would be substantially lower.
